I am well aware that super_ is a skilled programmer.

The thing I don’t understand is why you automatically assumed that I have no programming knowledge whatsoever and therefore don’t understand what has been said in this thread.

item.title: Vectors messing up?
item.dc:creator: @pkedpker pkedpker
item.description:
@pkedpker wrote:

[quote=“ranger squad”]Recently, I have been working on a text game. But the vector that handles the monsters is messing up.
Here is where the monster is added:

And here is my addMonster method:

public void addMonster(Monster monster) { m_vecMonsters.addElement(monster); }

And here is the code that tells you if there is a monster in the room:

for (Enumeration e = playerLocation.getMonsters().elements(); e.hasMoreElements();) { Monster monster = (Monster) e.nextElement(); outputField.appendText ("\nThere is a " + monster.getName() + " in this room. [Strength Level: "+monster.getStrength()+"]"); }

The getMonsters() method:

@SuppressWarnings("rawtypes") public Vector getMonsters() { return (Vector) m_vecMonsters.clone(); }

But no matter what room I am in, it says there is a Horned Fly in it - this should only happen in location 4![/quote]

[quote=“ranger squad”]chri5, I do have a class for locations.

unlimitedorb:
Monster class - getName method:

/** * @return this.name the name of the monster */ public String getName() { return this.name; }

HornedFly class:

[code=java]package com.faroutgaming.textgame.monster;

public class HornedFly extends Monster {
public HornedFly() {
super(“Horned Fly”, 3, 2);
}
}
[/code][/quote]

l4.addMonster(new HornedFly()); <-- creates new HornedFly

when HornedFly is created
super(“Horned Fly”, 3, 2); <-- is passed onto the Monster class

does your Monster class have a setName(String name) ??

because using this

 public void addMonster(Monster monster) {
                m_vecMonsters.addElement(monster);
        }

if your Monster class doesn’t have a setName you can easily write it like this

 public void setName(String name) {
                this.name = name;
        }

if you do something like this

Monster monster = new HornedFly();
monster.setName("Whatever");
addMonster(monster);

now it will say

There is a Whatever in this room. [Strength Level: IDKThisVariableLoL]

[quote=“ranger squad”]And here is the code that tells you if there is a monster in the room:

for (Enumeration e = playerLocation.getMonsters().elements(); e.hasMoreElements();) { Monster monster = (Monster) e.nextElement(); outputField.appendText ("\nThere is a " + monster.getName() + " in this room. [Strength Level: "+monster.getStrength()+"]"); }

But no matter what room I am in, it says there is a Horned Fly in it - this should only happen in location 4![/quote]

There is many ways to fix this to only support the current room you are in, you say you are in location 4… why not when you switch locations clear the MonstersVector? so all the Horded Fly’s get removed.

If you don’t want to clear the MonstersVector why not just add some kind of conditional method like

bool isInLocation(int myLocation) {
    return myLocation != monsterLocation;
}

add that to Monster Class then you could do.

for (Enumeration e = playerLocation.getMonsters().elements(); e.hasMoreElements();) { Monster monster = (Monster) e.nextElement(); if(!monster.isInLocation(myLocation)) continue; outputField.appendText ("\nThere is a " + monster.getName() + " in this room. [Strength Level: "+monster.getStrength()+"]"); }

But why load up all monsters you see into a huge monsterArray… waste of looping cycles you have to clear them when you switch rooms so your game won’t take up too much memory (huge array) or cpu (long looping).

Read full topic

item.title: Vectors messing up?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I would probably have a Room class something like:

[code]
class Room {

private Exit north, east, south, west;
private Collection<Monster> monsters;
private Collection<String> messages;

public Room(Exit north, Exit east, Exit south, Exit west) {
    //initialise variables here
}

public Collection<Monster> getMonsters() {
    return monsters;
}

}[/code]
you can also have sub classes of room for different types of rooms with tasks or puzzles, PuzzleRoom etc.
then in the player class, or whatever you call it have a Room variable for the current room and just call room.getMonsters(); try this see if you still get an error.

but to fix your current problem super_ is more than likely right, your list will be static

Read full topic

item.title: Vectors messing up?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

lesterknome:

Why make a new class for every Monster? Why not just define all of them in your initial Enum Monsters, Add them to a hashmap. Then use get(room) to return the Monster object then get the rest of the data from there?

I’m not sure if that would even be necessary. I suppose you could just have a Monster class, and maybe just an enum MonsterType, that has like spider, horned fly, etc. Probably something like this:

public final class Monster {
    public enum MonsterType {
        HORNED_FLY("Horned fly");

        private String name_;

        private MonsterType(String name) {
            name_ = name;
        }

        public String getName() {
            return name_;
        }
    }

    private MonsterType type_;

    public Monster(MonsterType type) {
        type_ = type;
    }

    public MonsterType getType() {
        return type_;
    }
}

and then just do

room.addMonster(new Monster(MonsterType.HORNED_FLY));

You could also, as an alternative, create a MonsterDefinition class, so that you could possibly load it from an external source, instead of having to recompile every time.

Read full topic

item.title: Vectors messing up?
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

The best thing to do in your code is to use a higher level interface, like List, except where you initialize it. Then it allows you to easily switch between different implementations such as ArrayList, Vector, LinkedList, etc.

Read full topic

/** * @return this.name the name of the monster */ public String getName() { return this.name; }

item.title: Vectors messing up?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

There’s only enough information here to make guesses. My guess is that the Monster class method getName() has a default value of Horned Fly, and since you’re not casting down to a specific monster it’ll print whatever is the default value in Monster.

BTW, Using Vector is generally considered bad practice now because of concurrency issues. A Vector is really just an ArrayList, anyway.

Read full topic
